Hilbert spaces and their linear functions play a central role in quantum theory. We provide a purely categorical definition of Hilbert spaces and of the category of linear operators on them. This definition is independent of any analytical structure. It is based on a notion of category equivalence, which is a categorical generalization of the notion of isomorphism. The axioms of this paper are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The paper also has a more general interest for the theory of categories.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used to ensure their replication and propagation. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated factors (ISFs) in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. This interaction is required for Orf6 to block nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings have important implications for the development of antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect crop yields. We use a statistical model to project how maize yields will change in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Herbivores are essential components of ecosystems, but their interactions with plants are often difficult to study. DNA metabarcoding is a powerful technique for identifying species in complex mixtures of DNA. We used this method to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven large mammalian herbivores in a semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species, even pairs of closely related species. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages. Our findings also highlight the importance of plant diversity in structuring LMH communities. These insights may help to explain the coexistence of LMH in semiarid savannas, where they are abundant but rarely observed together. Our results suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile. The majority of businesses plan to apply for a loan under the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a major environmental problem. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. The origin of presolar grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma. A majority of the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950. The expansion has been driven by the motorized fleet, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous, but it contributes only a quarter of the global engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years.

Reproductive output is limited by maternal energy availability. This is true for all species, including humans. However, the mechanisms by which this is accomplished are species-specific. Here, we show that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of mammalian reproductive biology. It also has implications for the evolution of human reproductive output. Copyright © 2015. Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein implicated in several neurodegenerative diseases. In multiple system atrophy (MSA), α-syn accumulates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to control many of these functions using a network of communication channels. This paper describes the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells. The network is surprisingly effective at communicating information.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. These include signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages.

We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the proper functioning of the channels. We have also shown that this residue is essential for the proper functioning of the channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health. The gut microbiome is also dynamic, with members changing over time. The gut microbiome is influenced by the host, diet, and the gut environment. The gut environment is influenced by the gut microbiota itself. The gut microbiota is influenced by the host. This feedback loop is complex and difficult to study. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. These fungi are abundant in the gut, but their role in the microbiome is unknown. We show that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products that could regulate the microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could regulate the gut microbiome. This could have implications for human health.

Anxiety is a common feature of many psychiatric disorders. However, the mechanisms underlying anxiety-related social deficits are largely unknown. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We further show that this low probability to become dominant is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. These findings are supported by pharmacological approaches. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that this brain region is involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is highly dynamic and is regulated by multiple mechanisms. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts. IGF2BP1 is expressed in adult bone marrow and is silenced in fetal liver. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by reduced expression of the alpha-globin gene and increased expression of the gamma-globin gene. The mechanism of this reprogramming is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies. Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Cancer cells are characterized by metabolic reprogramming, which is essential for their survival and proliferation. In this study, we found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1-mediated ferroptosis resistance can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. These findings suggest that ferroptosis-inducing agents may be used to sensitize cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutations to ferroptosis. This combination therapy may be effective in treating cancer patients with these mutations. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of heart failure prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of adverse effects. Here, we show that the major class of calcium channel blockers activate store-operated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. This process is mediated by the calcium sensor STIM1. Our findings may lead to the development of new drugs with fewer side effects. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring, and used adaptive management. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of this policy on biodiversity. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. However, the policy failed to reverse the decline of older forests. The NWFP needs to be complemented by a strategy to conserve older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We use a combination of molecular modeling and high-throughput screening to design acylide antibiotics. We show that the designed compounds are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This approach can be used to develop new antibiotics for other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The network architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems. The proposed network architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed network architecture is easier to train and apply in practice.

The Lake Malawi region is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth. The lake is also a critical component of the global hydrological cycle. We present a 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi. The record shows a dramatic shift in effective moisture at the MPT, which coincides with a change in the species flock of endemic cichlid fishes. The shift in hydroclimate is consistent with a change in the orbital forcing of climate. The record also shows that the lake has been much lower in the past, and that the species flock has been exposed to periods of extreme drought. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of the species flock and the impact of hydroclimate variability on the diversification of endemic species. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces the feeling of sleepiness, and delays the circadian clock. These effects are likely to have important consequences for performance and safety. This study also shows that the effects of electronic devices on sleep are not trivial. This knowledge is important for understanding the impact of these devices on health and safety. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1.2-ka global climate event that is often attributed to a bolide impact. However, the evidence for an impact-induced cooling is controversial. We show that the osmium isotope composition of magnetic grains and bulk sediment from the YDB sites in North America are consistent with a terrestrial origin of osmium. The osmium in the magnetic grains and bulk sediment is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Grenville osmium is consistent with that in spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania. The spherules are 1.5-Ga Grenville terrain ejecta. The spherules and their leachates have low 187Os/188Os ratios, indicating that the osmium in the spherules is likely terrestrial. Thus, the YDB spherules are a compelling piece of evidence for an impact-induced cooling.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses. However, its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we report that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice results in a variety of autoimmunity. This is not the case for congenital deficiency. Moreover, CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4–deficient mice have more severe collagen-induced arthritis, they are protected against peptide-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. They also suggest that CTLA-4 may be a potential target for the treatment of autoimmunity. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals. However, the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We reconstructed the phylogeny of beetles using 4,818 genes for 146 species. We estimated the timing and rates of beetle diversification using 89 genes for 521 species. We traced the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose using 154 genomes or transcriptomes. We found that beetles diversified in the presence of angiosperms, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes encoded in their genomes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles. These results provide insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a fundamental principle of the immune system. However, antibodies can mutate and lose their ability to neutralize viruses. This can lead to the emergence of new variants that are resistant to antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to optimize antibodies to neutralize emerging variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the Delta variant. We show that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our approach can potentially be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-’2 variants. This could help to reduce the risk of viral resistance and the emergence of new variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that the amount of complement component 1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased risk for multiple sclerosis, a disease characterized by complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This study also provides a mechanism for how APOE may influence the risk for AD. This article is protected by copyright.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We use a persistent embryo method and molecular dynamics simulations to study the nucleation of iron. Our results show that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase, which is more energetically favorable than the hcp phase. The second step is the transformation of the bcc phase to the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is composed of bcc iron, which is in contrast to the hcp phase.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on brain function and for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse. Copyright © 2015. Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most accurate machine learning models for language processing are also the most accurate models of the underlying neural data. This suggests that the brain’s language machinery is tuned to predict the next word in a sentence. We also find that model architecture is a strong predictor of model performance. These results provide computational evidence for the predictive processing hypothesis of language comprehension. They also suggest that the brain may be constantly fine-tuning its language machinery to improve predictions of upcoming words. Such a mechanism could help explain why we are constantly improving our language skills throughout our lives. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful approach to machine learning. However, it is still a black box. We show that the success of DL is due to the fact that it is a very well-conditioned approach. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities. However, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of these is the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This article discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 y. It shows that the study’s critical design flaws went completely unnoticed. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis. The latter is associated with a rare, progressive, and fatal disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis. We also found that M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. These findings suggest that M. lepromatosis may be neuropathogenic. Phylogenetic analyses indicate that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae. These results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related. The entanglement dynamics is usually studied by means of numerical simulations. However, the entanglement entropy is a local observable, whereas thermodynamics is a global observable. Therefore, an exact computation of the entanglement dynamics was available so far only for noninteracting systems. We show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be computed exactly. This is achieved by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency. The only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development, COVI-VAC, is based on recoding the viral spike protein with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In vivo, COVI-VAC vaccination reduced lung viral loads, resulted in undetectable virus in the brain, and protected hamsters from almost all SARS-CoV-2–associated weight loss. This vaccine is highly attenuated and is protective at a single intranasal dose in a relevant in vivo model. These properties support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of plague today. The brain is the most complex and expensive organ in the human body. It is also the most vulnerable. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key issue in biology. The brain is made of neurons, the basic units of information processing in the nervous system. The number of neurons in the brain is the main determinant of its information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of the brain is characterized by the increase in the number of neurons. This is true for all vertebrates, including humans. The number of neurons in the brain is also the main determinant of the evolution of the intelligence of vertebrates.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is still poorly understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a molecular understanding of ADF’s function in cells. They also provide a general mechanism for understanding how mechanical forces can enhance chemical reactions. This mechanism may be relevant to many other biological processes. Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food supply. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food-seeking behavior are not well understood. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on body weight and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of high-calorie foods. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the settlement of other islands. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is widespread and has been shown to impact mRNA stability. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can also impact protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the recruitment of the elongation factor eEF-Tu and the initiation of protein synthesis. We also find that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to a Ψ-containing codon. These findings have implications for how Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can impact protein synthesis. The presence of Ψ in mRNAs may also impact the translation of noncoding RNAs. Our findings suggest that Ψ in mRNAs can have subtle effects on protein synthesis. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We show that feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes. This finding is robust to a range of sensitivity analyses. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. We use a comparative approach to test the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a size attractor by the unique energetic demands of the aquatic environment. We find that the evolution of aquatic mammals is consistent with this hypothesis.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease worldwide. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold. The rhinovirus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that the replication of rhinovirus is temperature dependent in primary mouse airway cells. We also show that the replication of rhinovirus is dependent on the type I IFN response. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments. Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease. The atheroprone flow environment is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. This expansion has increased the risk of wildfire to people, property, and the environment. We provide a synthesis of the literature on human-caused wildfires in the United States. We show that human-caused wildfires have become the dominant cause of wildfires in the United States. We also provide recommendations for reducing the risk of human-caused wildfires. These recommendations include increasing awareness of the risks of human-caused wildfires, improving management of human-caused wildfires, and reducing the risk of human-caused wildfires through fuel management. These recommendations are important for reducing the risk of wildfire in the United States.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results suggest that physical improvements in cities are not random but rather are driven by the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results have implications for urban planning and for the study of urban change.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood. However, the treatment must be given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae. This loss of symbiosis is often assumed to be the result of heat stress, but the underlying mechanisms are still debated. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress increases the release of ammonium from the coral host, which in turn promotes the growth of algal symbionts and the retention of photosynthates. These processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is severely limited. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Recombination is essential for genome stability and the generation of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. This suggests that the initiation of recombination may have been conserved in the evolution of eukaryotes. Our results also reveal that recombination initiation is not uniform across genes. The resting brain is organized into functional networks. The present study provides a method for identifying and validating these networks. The 5′ cap structure is a ubiquitous modification of mRNA that is essential for efficient translation. The existence of 5′ modifications in RNA other than tRNA and rRNA has been controversial. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ modification in nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNA. This modification is found on subsets of transcripts and is not present on the same transcripts without the modification. Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The mechanisms underlying the development of this disorder are not fully understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence. The tomato is a model system for studying fruit ripening and the biosynthesis of volatile chemicals. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This pathway is unique to tomato fruit and is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, but how this is organized is debated. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the map of space, are organized separately from other cell types. This suggests that grid cells might have a unique neural code. Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study shows that the FT gene in dodder is not involved in flowering regulation. We all feel connected to others. But how do we know when we feel connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cells, the sinoatrial cells (SACSs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is tightly regulated. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cells of the SAN and that its deletion in mice results in a loss of the sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores in these cells. This loss of Ca2+ stores results in a loss of the ability of these cells to generate a regular heart rhythm. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ stores in specialized cells of the heart. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect plants against insect herbivores. This study also provides a basis for further research on the mechanisms of Si-mediated insect resistance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still unclear. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. They also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the macrophage lipidome. Language is a complex cognitive ability that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a different approach to memory than the traditional view of sustained, elevated firing rates. Our results suggest that memory is supported by a mechanism that is adaptive, context-sensitive, and sensitive to serial order. This mechanism may be important for language processing.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. The retina is a unique tissue that is challenged by both high levels of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. Modern farm machinery is responsible for the vast majority of soil compaction. We show that the increase in capacity of farm machinery has led to higher subsoil stresses that now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning.
